primary_diagnosis: Chronic Kidney Disease Stage 3
medications: Lisinopril 10 mg daily
Furosemide 20 mg twice daily
dietary_restrictions: Low sodium (≤2 g/day), fluid restriction 1.5 L/day, limit potassium if hyperkalemic
follow_up: Nephrology clinic in 2 weeks; repeat BMP and urine test in 1 week
warning_signs: Swelling, shortness of breath, decreased urine output, sudden weight gain (>2 kg/48 h)
discharge_instructions: Monitor blood pressure and weight daily; bring medication list to clinic; hold NSAIDs and report dizziness or lightheadedness

primary_diagnosis: Community-acquired Pneumonia (moderate)
medications: Amoxicillin-clavulanate 875/125 mg twice daily for 7 days
Albuterol inhaler as needed
dietary_restrictions: No specific restrictions; maintain hydration
follow_up: Primary care visit in 48–72 hours or earlier if worse; chest X-ray in 6–8 weeks if persistent symptoms
warning_signs: Increasing shortness of breath, high fever >38.5°C (101.3°F), chest pain, confusion
discharge_instructions: Finish antibiotics; use inhaler as directed; rest and hydrate; seek urgent care for worsening breathing or fever

primary_diagnosis: Acute ST-elevation Myocardial Infarction (post-PCI)
medications: Aspirin 81 mg daily
Clopidogrel 75 mg daily
Atorvastatin 80 mg nightly
Metoprolol tartrate 25 mg twice daily
dietary_restrictions: Low saturated fat, low sodium; heart-healthy diet
follow_up: Cardiology clinic in 1 week; cardiac rehabilitation referral
warning_signs: Chest pain or pressure, fainting, worsening shortness of breath, new palpitations
discharge_instructions: Take antiplatelet therapy as prescribed (do not stop without cardiology); slowly increase activity per rehab plan; emergency department for recurrent chest pain

primary_diagnosis: Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus — Hyperglycemia (transitioned to basal-bolus insulin)
medications: Insulin glargine 20 units nightly (basal)
Insulin lispro with meals per sliding scale
Metformin 500 mg twice daily
dietary_restrictions: Carbohydrate-counted meals; avoid simple sugars; maintain consistent meal timing
follow_up: Endocrinology or diabetes educator in 1 week to titrate insulin; blood glucose log review
warning_signs: Blood glucose <70 mg/dL or >300 mg/dL persistently, excessive thirst, vomiting
discharge_instructions: Teach insulin administration and hypoglycemia treatment (15 g fast-acting carbohydrate); keep BG log and bring to follow-up; do not stop metformin without consulting provider

primary_diagnosis: Left ischemic stroke with minor residual right-sided weakness
medications: Aspirin 81 mg daily
Atorvastatin 40 mg nightly
Losartan 50 mg daily
dietary_restrictions: Low sodium; heart-healthy diet
follow_up: Neurology clinic in 2 weeks; outpatient physical and occupational therapy
warning_signs: Sudden worsening of weakness, new slurred speech, facial droop, severe headache
discharge_instructions: Continue medications; perform prescribed home exercises; call emergency services for signs of recurrent stroke

primary_diagnosis: Acute Appendicitis — Post laparoscopic appendectomy (uncomplicated)
medications: Acetaminophen 500–1000 mg every 6–8 hours as needed (max 3 g/day)
Cephalexin 500 mg twice daily for 3 days (if indicated)
dietary_restrictions: Advance diet as tolerated; start with clear fluids then soft diet
follow_up: Surgical clinic in 7–14 days
warning_signs: Fever >38°C, increasing abdominal pain, redness or drainage at incision, vomiting
discharge_instructions: Keep incisions clean and dry; avoid heavy lifting >10–15 kg and strenuous activity for 2–4 weeks; resume normal diet as tolerated

primary_diagnosis: Chronic Heart Failure — Acute decompensation (now euvolemic)
medications: Furosemide 40 mg daily (adjust per weight)
Lisinopril 5 mg daily
Bisoprolol 2.5 mg daily
dietary_restrictions: Strict low sodium ≤2 g/day; fluid restriction 1.5 L/day
follow_up: Heart failure clinic or cardiology in 1 week; daily weights and home monitoring
warning_signs: Rapid weight gain (>2 kg/48 h), worsening shortness of breath, increasing edema, lightheadedness
discharge_instructions: Weigh daily and record; take diuretics as prescribed; seek urgent care for worsening breathing or swelling

primary_diagnosis: Community-acquired Cellulitis (left lower limb)
medications: Cephalexin 500 mg four times daily for 7 days
Ibuprofen 200–400 mg every 6–8 hours as needed
dietary_restrictions: No specific restrictions; maintain hydration
follow_up: Primary care or wound clinic in 48–72 hours to reassess
warning_signs: Increasing redness, spreading warmth, fever, new drainage, severe pain
discharge_instructions: Elevate the limb, keep dressing clean, complete antibiotic course; seek urgent care for systemic symptoms

primary_diagnosis: Acute Exacerbation of COPD (moderate) — discharged on inhaled therapy
medications: Tiotropium inhaler 18 mcg once daily
Salmeterol-fluticasone inhaler two puffs twice daily
Prednisone 30 mg daily for 5 days
dietary_restrictions: No specific restrictions; avoid respiratory irritants
follow_up: Pulmonology or primary care in 1 week; smoking cessation resources if applicable
warning_signs: Worsening breathlessness, increasing sputum production or purulence, fever, confusion
discharge_instructions: Use inhalers with spacer if needed; follow prednisone taper instructions; seek urgent care for worsening respiratory distress

primary_diagnosis: Uncomplicated Urinary Tract Infection
medications: Nitrofurantoin 100 mg twice daily for 5 days
Phenazopyridine 200 mg three times daily for 2 days as needed for dysuria
dietary_restrictions: No specific restrictions; drink fluids
follow_up: Primary care if symptoms persist after treatment
warning_signs: Fever, flank pain, vomiting, persistent dysuria or hematuria
discharge_instructions: Complete antibiotics; expect urine discoloration with phenazopyridine; return if fever or back pain

primary_diagnosis: Total Hip Arthroplasty — Postoperative (right)
medications: Oxycodone 5–10 mg every 4–6 hours as needed (use lowest effective dose)
Acetaminophen 500 mg every 6–8 hours as needed
Enoxaparin 40 mg subcutaneously daily for DVT prophylaxis for 14 days
dietary_restrictions: Advance diet as tolerated
follow_up: Orthopedics in 2 weeks; physical therapy starting within 48–72 hours
warning_signs: Increasing leg swelling/pain, chest pain or shortness of breath, wound drainage, fever
discharge_instructions: Use walker per PT recommendations; wound care instructions provided; perform home exercises; avoid high-impact activity for 6–12 weeks

primary_diagnosis: Acute Pancreatitis (mild) — resolved
medications: Ondansetron 4 mg as needed for nausea
Acetaminophen 500 mg as needed for pain
dietary_restrictions: Initially clear fluids then low-fat diet as tolerated; avoid alcohol and high-fat meals
follow_up: Gastroenterology clinic in 2–4 weeks; consider imaging or triglycerides check if indicated
warning_signs: Worsening abdominal pain, persistent vomiting, fever, jaundice
discharge_instructions: Resume low-fat diet gradually; avoid alcohol; seek care for worsening pain or inability to tolerate PO intake

primary_diagnosis: Acute Deep Vein Thrombosis (left leg)
medications: Apixaban 10 mg twice daily for 7 days, then 5 mg twice daily (initiation regimen)
dietary_restrictions: No specific restrictions required for DOACs; avoid significant alcohol
follow_up: Hematology or vascular medicine in 1 week; duplex ultrasound arranged per clinic
warning_signs: Increasing leg swelling, pain, redness; sudden shortness of breath or chest pain (seek emergency)
discharge_instructions: Take anticoagulant exactly as prescribed; avoid NSAIDs unless approved; use compression stockings as directed; report any bleeding

primary_diagnosis: Acute Gastroenteritis (viral, hydrated)
medications: Oral rehydration as needed; Ondansetron 4 mg as needed for nausea
dietary_restrictions: BRAT diet initially (bananas, rice, applesauce, toast); advance as tolerated
follow_up: Primary care if symptoms >48–72 hours or worsening
warning_signs: High fever, persistent vomiting, bloody diarrhea, dizziness or signs of dehydration
discharge_instructions: Maintain hydration with ORS; avoid dairy until tolerated; return if unable to keep liquids down or signs of dehydration

primary_diagnosis: Acute Exacerbation of Asthma (controlled, discharged on inhalers)
medications: Budesonide-formoterol inhaler two puffs twice daily
Short course oral prednisone 40 mg daily for 5 days
Salbutamol inhaler for rescue
dietary_restrictions: No specific restrictions
follow_up: Pulmonology or primary care in 1 week; provide asthma action plan
warning_signs: Increasing wheeze, difficulty speaking, use of accessory muscles, peak flow <50% of personal best
discharge_instructions: Follow asthma action plan; correct inhaler technique; seek emergency care for severe breathing difficulty

primary_diagnosis: Community-acquired Bacterial Meningitis — completed IV antibiotics inpatient; switched to oral for course completion
medications: Amoxicillin 1 g three times daily to complete prescribed course (per culture sensitivities)
dietary_restrictions: No specific restrictions
follow_up: Infectious disease clinic in 1 week; repeat clinical exam and labs as arranged
warning_signs: High fever, severe headache, neck stiffness, new neurological deficits, seizures
discharge_instructions: Complete antibiotic course; avoid driving if on sedating meds; return for any new neurological symptoms

primary_diagnosis: Acute Exacerbation of Major Depressive Disorder (stabilized)
medications: Sertraline 50 mg daily
Lorazepam 0.5 mg PRN for severe anxiety (short-term use)
dietary_restrictions: No specific restrictions
follow_up: Psychiatry outpatient within 1 week; safety plan and crisis numbers provided
warning_signs: Worsening depression, suicidal thoughts, new impulsivity or severe agitation
discharge_instructions: Continue medications as directed; attend psychotherapy and psychiatry follow-up; seek immediate help for suicidal ideation

primary_diagnosis: Acute Kidney Injury (prerenal) — resolved with fluids
medications: Hold NSAIDs; resume home meds as advised; adjust dosing of renally cleared meds
dietary_restrictions: Maintain hydration; avoid high potassium foods until follow-up if hyperkalemia risk
follow_up: Nephrology or primary care BMP in 3–7 days
warning_signs: Decreased urine output, swelling, persistent nausea/vomiting
discharge_instructions: Monitor urine output and weight; avoid nephrotoxins (NSAIDs, contrast) unless cleared; bring medication list to follow-up

primary_diagnosis: Community-acquired Otitis Media — unilateral
medications: Amoxicillin 500 mg three times daily for 7 days
Acetaminophen for pain/fever
dietary_restrictions: No specific restrictions
follow_up: Primary care in 48–72 hours if not improving; ENT referral if recurrent
warning_signs: Severe ear pain, high fever, dizziness, hearing loss
discharge_instructions: Finish antibiotics; warm compress for pain; avoid water in the ear until healed

primary_diagnosis: Acute Exacerbation of Crohn's Disease — stabilized
medications: Budesonide 9 mg daily taper as outpatient (per GI plan)
Mesalamine 1.2 g twice daily
dietary_restrictions: Low-residue diet during flare; avoid high-fiber foods until symptoms improve
follow_up: Gastroenterology in 2 weeks; medication optimization discussion
warning_signs: High fever, severe abdominal pain, persistent bleeding, inability to tolerate oral intake
discharge_instructions: Adhere to medication taper; stay hydrated; seek care for severe symptoms

primary_diagnosis: Superficial Partial-Thickness Burn — left forearm (healed/no graft)
medications: Topical silver sulfadiazine as instructed for 3–5 days
Acetaminophen for pain as needed
dietary_restrictions: No specific restrictions
follow_up: Burn/wound clinic in 5–7 days
warning_signs: Increased redness, foul odor or purulent drainage, fever, increasing pain
discharge_instructions: Keep dressing clean and dry; change per wound clinic instructions; tetanus status reviewed

primary_diagnosis: Atrial Fibrillation with Rapid Ventricular Response (rate controlled)
medications: Metoprolol succinate 50 mg daily (for rate control)
Apixaban 5 mg twice daily (anticoagulation)
dietary_restrictions: Avoid excess alcohol and large caffeine intake; maintain consistent diet
follow_up: Cardiology within 1 week; anticoagulation clinic/INR not required for DOAC but monitor renal function
warning_signs: Palpitations with dizziness/syncope, chest pain, shortness of breath
discharge_instructions: Take anticoagulant as prescribed; nightly heart rate log recommended; seek immediate care for signs of stroke or major bleeding

primary_diagnosis: Preeclampsia without severe features — postpartum stable
medications: Labetalol 200 mg twice daily as needed for BP (per OB plan)
dietary_restrictions: No specific restrictions; maintain moderate sodium intake per obstetrics guidance
follow_up: Obstetrics office in 3 days and blood pressure check within 48 hours
warning_signs: Severe headache, visual changes, severe right upper quadrant pain, sudden swelling
discharge_instructions: Monitor BP at home; avoid strenuous activity; seek emergency care for severe symptoms

primary_diagnosis: Severe Bacterial Cellulitis with IV antibiotics completed — improving
medications: Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole DS one tablet twice daily for 7 days (per culture)
Ibuprofen for pain
dietary_restrictions: No specific restrictions
follow_up: Wound clinic or primary care in 48–72 hours
warning_signs: Spreading redness, fever, increasing pain, new drainage
discharge_instructions: Complete oral antibiotics; continue limb elevation; return for worsening infection

primary_diagnosis: Iron Deficiency Anemia — outpatient oral iron started
medications: Ferrous sulfate 325 mg (65 mg elemental iron) once daily at night with vitamin C or orange juice
dietary_restrictions: Avoid taking iron with calcium or dairy; take on empty stomach if tolerated
follow_up: Hematology/primary care in 4 weeks with CBC and iron studies
warning_signs: Severe weakness, shortness of breath, chest pain, black/tarry stools (report GI bleeding)
discharge_instructions: Expect stool darkening; continue iron for at least 3 months after hemoglobin normalizes; report GI symptoms

primary_diagnosis: Acute Bacterial Sinusitis
medications: Amoxicillin 500 mg three times daily for 7 days
Saline nasal rinse PRN
Ibuprofen PRN
dietary_restrictions: No specific restrictions
follow_up: Primary care if symptoms persist beyond 10 days or worsen
warning_signs: High fever, severe facial pain, vision changes, swelling around the eye
discharge_instructions: Complete antibiotic course; use saline nasal irrigation; seek urgent care for ocular symptoms

primary_diagnosis: Uncomplicated Low-risk Skin Abscess — I&D performed
medications: Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole DS one tablet twice daily for 5 days (if indicated)
Acetaminophen for pain
dietary_restrictions: No specific restrictions
follow_up: Wound clinic in 48–72 hours for packing removal and reassessment
warning_signs: Increasing redness, fever, spreading cellulitis, increased drainage
discharge_instructions: Keep wound covered and clean; change dressings as instructed; complete antibiotics if prescribed

primary_diagnosis: Pneumothorax — small, stable, discharged with outpatient follow-up
medications: Analgesics as needed (acetaminophen or ibuprofen)
dietary_restrictions: No specific restrictions; avoid air travel until cleared
follow_up: Thoracic surgery or pulmonology in 3–5 days with repeat chest X-ray
warning_signs: Sudden increased shortness of breath, chest pain, lightheadedness
discharge_instructions: Avoid heavy exertion and air travel until specialist clearance; return for worsening symptoms

primary_diagnosis: Migraine, resolved with treatment
medications: Sumatriptan 50–100 mg as needed at onset (per prior tolerability)
Propranolol 40 mg nightly for prevention (started outpatient)
dietary_restrictions: Avoid known dietary triggers (caffeine excess, certain cheeses) per patient history
follow_up: Neurology or headache clinic in 4 weeks
warning_signs: New focal neurological signs, severe atypical headache unlike prior migraines, persistent vomiting
discharge_instructions: Use acute medication at onset; keep headache diary; seek urgent care for atypical features

primary_diagnosis: Superficial Venous Thrombosis (conservative management)
medications: NSAID (e.g., ibuprofen) for pain as tolerated; consider short course low-molecular-weight heparin if propagation risk
dietary_restrictions: No specific restrictions
follow_up: Vascular clinic in 1 week; duplex ultrasound if symptoms persist
warning_signs: Worsening leg pain/swelling, signs of DVT, sudden shortness of breath
discharge_instructions: Use compression stockings, elevate limb, mobilize regularly; return for worsening symptoms

primary_diagnosis: Acute Exacerbation of Alcoholic Hepatitis — improved
medications: Thiamine 100 mg daily (IV/IM initially then PO as indicated)
Naltrexone deferred until abstinence confirmed (per addiction consult)
dietary_restrictions: Abstain from alcohol; moderate protein; avoid hepatotoxic medications
follow_up: Hepatology and addiction medicine within 1–2 weeks
warning_signs: Jaundice worsening, confusion, bleeding, severe abdominal pain
discharge_instructions: Strict alcohol abstinence; nutritional support; seek urgent care for signs of hepatic decompensation

primary_diagnosis: Breast Abscess — I&D completed, cultures obtained
medications: Amoxicillin-clavulanate 875/125 mg twice daily for 7–10 days
Acetaminophen for pain
dietary_restrictions: No specific restrictions; breastfeeding guidance provided if applicable
follow_up: Surgical or breast clinic in 48–72 hours
warning_signs: Increasing pain, fever, spreading redness, increased drainage
discharge_instructions: Keep dressing clean; continue antibiotics; lactation support if breastfeeding

primary_diagnosis: Localized Rheumatoid Arthritis Flare — outpatient DMARDs resumed
medications: Prednisone 10 mg daily short course then taper
Resume methotrexate 15 mg weekly (per rheumatology)
dietary_restrictions: Avoid alcohol while on methotrexate; maintain balanced diet
follow_up: Rheumatology in 2 weeks; lab monitoring arranged
warning_signs: Fever, new infections, unusual bruising or bleeding, severe GI symptoms
discharge_instructions: Follow up for lab monitoring; avoid live vaccines while immunosuppressed; report signs of infection promptly

primary_diagnosis: Early-stage Sepsis (source: urinary) — stabilized and completed IV therapy
medications: Oral antibiotic to complete course per urine culture sensitivities
Acetaminophen as needed
dietary_restrictions: Maintain hydration and balanced diet
follow_up: Primary care or infectious disease in 3–7 days
warning_signs: Fever, persistent tachycardia, lightheadedness, decreased urine output
discharge_instructions: Finish antibiotics; monitor temperature and urine output; seek urgent care for signs of recurrent sepsis
